thread.title: SpaceX to fly two paying customers on tourist trip around the moon in 2018, Elon Musk reveals
thread.title_full: SpaceX to fly two paying customers on tourist trip around the moon in 2018, Elon Musk reveals - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: SpaceX to fly two paying customers on tourist trip around the moon in 2018, Elon Musk reveals
text:
SpaceX to fly two paying customers on tourist trip around the moon in 2018, Elon Musk reveals Musk declined to identify the customers or say how much they would pay to fly on the week-long mission, except to say that it’s "nobody from Hollywood" Share Comments By Natalie Evans Jeff Parsons 23:31, 27 FEB 2017 Updated 23:33, 27 FEB 2017 Science Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Mum's horror as man tries to lure daughter away i Watch this video again Watch Next Elon Musk starts trailing Hyperloop passenger pods 1:26 Incredible onboard footage of rocket landing on s 0:30 Edelmira Barreira, Spain's 'SEX TSAR' talks of de 0:44 Kate Middleton sparkles in shawl as Queen celebra 0:35 HAS IAN BRADY'S SHOTGUN JUST BEEN FOUND ON SADDLE 1:19 Chrissy Teigen teases John Legend over lack of Os Bikers invade city dual carriageway and are surpr 0:58 'Are we on dope?' Anne Marie Morris goes on the o 0:55 Horror as huge rat runs rings round KFC staff bef 0:58 Four jailed for staged armed robbery at Rishton P 0:42 Family speak of horror as stroke victim faces thr 1:10 Video will play in SpaceX Dragon bolted into place at International Space Station Share this video Watch Next SpaceX plans to fly two paying customers on a tourist trip around the moon, boss Elon Musk has revealed.
The private launch company plans to use a spaceship which is under development for NASA astronauts and a heavy-lift rocket that has not yet flown.
The launch of the first-ever privately funded tourist flight beyond the International Space Station is tentatively targeted for late 2018, CEO Musk told reporters today.
He declined to identify the customers or say how much they would pay to fly on the week-long mission, except to say that it’s "nobody from Hollywood."
Read More Drone footage provides amazing view of SpaceX's successful rocket landing (Photo: Bloomberg) He also said the two prospective space tourists know each other.
“We would expect to do more than one mission of this nature,” he added. “This should be incredibly exciting."
SpaceX is getting better at landing its reusable rockets - and this time the private space company had an eye in the sky to capture the moment.
Musk's company was hoping for its third successful landing after delivering a payload into space.
To capture the moment, a drone was hovering with a clear view of the landing pad in Cape Canaveral, Florida, last week.
The landing was a success and the drone captured the amazingly smooth motion of the rocket touching down to the ground. You can see the results for yourself in the video above.
Read More Elon Musk's SpaceX rocket to resume flying as cost of explosion revealed as quarter of a BILLION dollars https://www.instagram.com/p/BQspL7Qhv1v/embed The drone footage was just one of the recorded viewpoints of the landing. The Falcon 9 rocket also had cameras strapped to its body and on the ground near the landing pad.
Touchdown came after the rocket had delivered supplies and science equipment to the astronauts aboard the ISS.
This was also SpaceX's first launch (and landing) from Launch Complex 39A - the site that hosted numerous Apollo launches as well as the final Shuttle mission in 2011.
Read More Holidays on the moon will be possible in a DECADE - but a ticket will cost you £8000 It could pave the way for the private space company to begin using the launch pad more frequently in the future. Especially if they can continue to land and re-use rockets so successfully.
Musk also used Instagram to post another video of the Falcon 9 coming back down to Earth.
